metadata.titleEn: Hf isotope data of detrital zircons from metasedimentary rocks in Hainan Island
metadata.description: This data includes Hf isotopic data of detrital zircons from metasedimentary rocks in Hainan Island. In 2017, in-situ Lu Hf isotopic analysis of zircons was performed at the State Key Laboratory of isotopes, Guangzhou Institute of geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, with Neptune plus MC-ICP-MS and resolutionm-50 laser ablation system as instruments. Laser parameter spot 45 μ m. The repetition rate is 8 Hz and the energy is 80 MJ. He was used as carrier gas and a small amount of nitrogen was added to improve the sample signal. Penglai zircon is used as standard sample in the test, with 176hf / 177hf of 0.2828906 ±  10 (2 σ,  Li et al., 2010b). The analysis point and U-Pb dating analysis point are at the same location or near the same zircon. See Wu et al. (2006a) for detailed analysis method.
metadata.instructions: It is stored in word format and the name of the file is "HF SL". The sample name is "YY DD", where YY represents the sampling location and DD represents the sample number.

background: Hainan Island, an epicontinental-type island, is located on the northern margin of the South China sea and characterized by multistage continental rifting and assembly as well as episodic crustal growth likely since late Archean. The most important epochs for the Hainan crustal growth likely include Paleoproterozoic of ca. 2.0 Ga age and late Mesoproterozoic to early Neoproterozoic of ca. 1.0 Ga age, which probably are linked to the evolutions of the Paleoproterozoic to Mesoproterozoic Columbia supercontinent and the Mesoproterozoic to Early Neoproterozoic Rodina supercontinent, respectively. Previous reconstructions of Rodinia supercontinent usually placed Hainan Island as part of the Cathaysia Block, South China and thus, South China (including Hainan Island) was considered to be situated between western Laurentia and southeastern Australia in the Rodinia, on the basis of the presence of the Mesoproterozoic (ca. 1.43 Ga) magmatic rocks in Hainan Island. In contrast, some researchers proposed that the South China was located on the periphery of Rodinia near western Australia and India based on zircon U-Pb geochronological data from both the Yangtze and Cathaysia blocks of South China.

Inferences about the continental crust evolution have largely come from the study of neodymium and hafnium isotope systematics. Since the Nd isotope system cannot resolve individual periods of crustal growth and the Hf isotopic analysis technology has gained great progresses, zircon Hf isotope data have been used increasingly to constrain the growth and differentiation of the continental crust. South China comprises the Cathaysia Block in the southeast and the Yangtze Block in the northwest, which were amalgamated during the Neoproterozoic due to the assembly of Rodinia. Hainan Island, separated from South China mainland by the Qiongzhou Strait, lies at the joint of the Eurasian plate, Indian-Australian plate and Pacific plate which makes the Island especially significant for understanding the continental margin accretion and evolution of East Asia.

Hafnium isotopic compositions of zircon grains were measured using a Neptune MC-ICPMS coupled with New Wave Merchantek LUV213 type laser system at the State Key Laboratory of Isotope Geochemistry, Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences (SKLIG-GIG, CAS). The late Mesoproterozoic to early Neoproterozoic Shilu Group and the early Neoproterozoic Shihuiding Formation are two important Precambrian successions in Hainan Island, and are also good source materials for investigating the Precambrian tectonic evolution of Hainan Island and even for encoding the tectonic position of the Cathaysia Block in Rodinia. The terrestrial continental crust can be defined as the unique feature which distinguishes earth from other planets in the solar system. The formation and evolution of the continental crust have always been the most important topic and debate in earth science.

Reconstruction of the paleo-geographical position of the relationship between two specific continents requires integration of multiple lines of evidence including understanding of the tectonic setting, orogenic histories, high-quality geochronological, crustal evolution, paleobiogeographic data, etc. (Li et al., 2008a). With the discovery of Neoproterozoic magmatic rocks along the Wuyi-Yunkai belt, school of researchers suggested that the Cathaysia Block was an active continental margin during Neoproterozoic time (Ling et al., 2003; Shu et al., 2008; Zhang et al., 2012; Wang et al., 2013b; Xia et al., 2015).
research objective: In this contribution, the in situ Lu-Hf isotopes of detrital zircons collected from the late Mesoproterozoic to early Neoproterozoic Shilu Group and the early Neoproterozoic Shihuiding Formation were performed to evaluate the growth and reworking of Hainan Island continental crust during Precambrian. Combined with previous reported studies, we further discussed the time of crust-mantle differentiation histories and the crustal evolution mode in Hainan Island as well as suggested the relationship between Hainan Island and the Cathaysia Block of South China before or during the assembly of Rodinia.

Thus, one of the key issues is that whether or not the 1.80–1.43 Ga crystalline rocks in Hainan Island can be interpreted as part of the Proterozoic basement rocks for the Cathaysia Block of South China.
challenges: The limited exposure and the multistage deformation of crystalline basement rocks led to diverse interpretations on the tectonic division of Hainan Island. Therefore, much more lines of evidence form stratigraphy, magmatism, geophysics and paleobiogeography are still needed to confirm or clarify the tectonic characteristics of Hainan Island.
methods: The present study is a follow-up work of the analyses of the detrital zircon U-Pb dating finished and subsequently published by Wang et al. (2015). Twelve samples which were previously analyzed for geochronology only were collected from the Shilu Group and overlying Shihuiding Formation for zircon Hf analysis.

In this study, five hundred and sixty-seven Hf isotopic spots were analyzed on the detrital zircons from the collected twelve samples. The Hf isotopic data was filtered sequentially using the following exclusion criteria from Belousova et al. (2010): (1) zircons with U-Pb age discordance over 10% were rejected; (2) zircons with formation age bigger than the model age were rejected; (3) zircons with Th/U <0.05 were rejected because of the potential for metamorphic origin. A total of one hundred and seventy-one zircon grains, collected from the Shihuiding Formation, were analyzed for Hf-isotope composition. A total of two hundred and seventy-two Hf-isotopic analyses on zircon grains from nine samples of the Shilu Group were obtained. In the Sixth sequence of Shilu Group, 177 Hf-isotopic analyses were conducted on zircon grains from six samples. For the Fifth sequence of Shilu Group, 19 hafnium analyses on sample sL5-D yielded variable 176Hf/177Hf ratios. Seventy-six Hf analyses on zircon grains from two samples of the Fourth sequence were implemented.
dataset: The results of 171 Hf-isotopic analyses on zircon grains from the Shihuiding Formation yield 176Hf/177Hf ratios between 0.280786 and 0.281188, 176Lu/177Hf ratios between 0.000228 and 0.003388, Hf model ages (T DMC) between 3.8 Ga and 1.2 Ga, and eHf(t) values ranging from -12.5 to +10.6. The analyzed results of 272 Hf-isotopic data on zircon grains from the Shilu Group exhibit a wide range of 176Hf/177Hf ratios (0.280810–0.282512), 176Lu/177Hf ratios (0.000062–0.004060), T DMC ages (3.7 Ga–1.1 Ga), and eHf(t) values (-20.5 to +12.3).
findings: The continental crust of Hainan Island maybe appeared firstly at ca. 4.0–3.8 Ga and then was reworked. Unambiguously, the crustal basement rocks in Hainan Island were formed mainly through reworking the previous continental components with minor input of juvenile materials. The generation of juvenile crust in Hainan Island predominantly occurred at ca. 2.7 Ga and ca. 1.5–1.0 Ga, which are consistent with that for the assembly of the Kenorland, and the Columbia breakup and subsequent amalgamation of the Rodinia, respectively. The present study further reveals that the crustal growths in Hainan Island are present at 2.7 Ga, 2.3 Ga and 2.1–1.8 Ga, which is more favorable to the episodic growth mode. Moreover, a rough trend of decreasing maximum crustal incubation time of Hainan Island demonstrates that the incubation time of the juvenile crust is shorter when compared with that of the Cathaysia Block in the late Mesoproterozoic.
These independent lines of evidence demonstrate that the Hainan Island was not adjacent to the Cathaysia Block of South China before the Neoproterozoic.

The similar predominate peaks in detrital zircon age patterns and the small age gap of the maximum depositional ages suggest a continuous sedimentation for both the Shilu Group and overlying Shihuiding Formation which originated from the same depositional system. The poor relationship between the periods of supercontinent assemblies and the Hf model age peaks may support the hypothesis of episodic crustal growth. Zircons Hf isotopic constrains demonstrate that 2.7 Ga, 2.3 Ga and 2.1–1.8 Ga are the three main continental crust growth periods in Hainan Island. The late Archean of ca. 2.7 Ga age and the Mesoproterozoic to Neoproterozoic transition of ca. 1.5–1.0 Ga age are the two important periods of juvenile crust growth in Hainan Island. Hainan Island likely did not share the same evolution history as the Cathaysia Block of South China before or during the Rodinia assembly, consistent with that both the continents do not have the same metamorphic basement.

Definition.Question: What are the main challenges associated with the tectonic division of regions like Hainan Island?
Definition.Answer: The main challenges associated with the tectonic division of regions like Hainan Island include limited exposure and multistage deformation of crystalline basement rocks, which lead to diverse interpretations on the tectonic division. More evidence from stratigraphy, magmatism, geophysics, and paleobiogeography are needed to confirm or clarify these characteristics.

Definition.Question: What criteria are commonly used to filter Hf isotopic data in geological studies?
Definition.Answer: Common criteria used to filter Hf isotopic data in geological studies include rejecting zircons with U-Pb age discordance over 10%, zircons with a formation age larger than the model age, and zircons with Th/U ratios less than 0.05 due to potential metamorphic origin.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the challenges of measuring Hf isotopes in zircon grains from multistage deformation of crystalline basement rocks?
Interpretation.Answer: The limited exposure and multistage deformation of crystalline basement rocks lead to diverse interpretations of Hainan Island's tectonic division, indicating that stratigraphy, magmatism, geophysics, and paleobiogeography evidence is needed to confirm tectonic characteristics.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for specific exclusion criteria, such as U-Pb age discordance or Th/U ratios, in filtering Hf isotopic data from detrital zircons?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The exclusion criteria are necessary to ensure the reliability and accuracy of the Hf isotopic data. Zircons with high U-Pb age discordance or low Th/U ratios may indicate metamorphic origins or inaccuracies in dating, which could lead to erroneous interpretations of crustal growth and differentiation histories.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of implementing stringent exclusion criteria on zircon Hf isotopic data analysis?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing stringent exclusion criteria on zircon Hf isotopic data analysis, such as rejecting zircons with U-Pb age discordance over 10%, could lead to a more reliable dataset by filtering out data points that might skew results. This may enhance the accuracy of crustal growth and differentiation studies, ensuring that only high-quality data is used for interpreting the geological history of regions like Hainan Island.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the rationale behind conducting in situ Lu-Hf isotopic analyses on detrital zircons from the Shilu Group and Shihuiding Formation for understanding the Precambrian crustal growth of Hainan Island?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to evaluate the growth and reworking of Hainan Island's continental crust during the Precambrian era. By analyzing these isotopic compositions, researchers aim to understand the timing and mode of crust-mantle differentiation and to suggest the relationship between Hainan Island and the Cathaysia Block of South China prior to or during the Rodinia assembly.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to establish exclusion criteria such as U-Pb age discordance and Th/U ratios when analyzing Hf isotopic data from zircon grains?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Implementing exclusion criteria is crucial to ensure the reliability and accuracy of Hf isotopic data. By rejecting zircons with certain discordance levels or Th/U ratios, researchers aim to filter out potential errors or biases that could arise from metamorphic origins or other discrepancies, thus providing a clearer understanding of the crustal evolution of Hainan Island.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of comparing the Hf isotopic data from Hainan Island with the periods of supercontinent assemblies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to explore whether there is a correlation between the periods of supercontinent assemblies and the Hf model age peaks. This comparison could provide insights into the episodic crustal growth patterns of Hainan Island and determine if its developmental history aligns with or diverges from the Cathaysia Block of South China.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are involved in the laser ablation process for analyzing zircon Hf isotopes and how do these steps ensure the accuracy of isotopic measurements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The laser ablation process for analyzing zircon Hf isotopes involves using a Neptune Plus MC-ICP-MS and RESOlution M-50 laser ablation system. The laser parameters include a beam diameter of 45 μm, a repetition rate of 8 Hz, and energy of 80 mJ. Helium is used as a carrier gas with a small amount of nitrogen added to enhance the sample signal. The Penglai zircon is used as a standard to test accuracy, with specific isotopic values provided for reference. Analysis points are either the same or near the U-Pb dating points on the zircon grains.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are the exclusion criteria applied to Hf isotopic data to filter results, and why are these criteria important in the context of zircon analysis?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The exclusion criteria for Hf isotopic data include rejecting zircons with U-Pb age discordance over 10%, formation ages larger than the model age, and Th/U ratios less than 0.05 due to potential metamorphic origins. These criteria are essential to ensure the reliability and accuracy of the isotopic analysis, focusing on crustal growth and differentiation by eliminating data that could skew the results due to discordance or metamorphic influences.

Enablement.Question: What specific technological advancements have enabled the precise in situ analysis of Lu-Hf isotopes in detrital zircons?
Enablement.Answer: The precise in situ analysis of Lu-Hf isotopes in detrital zircons was enabled by the use of Neptune Plus MC-ICP-MS and the RESOlution M-50 laser ablation system, which allow for accurate measurements of isotopic compositions. The inclusion of helium as a carrier gas and the addition of a small amount of nitrogen gas improved the sample signal during analysis.

Enablement.Question: How do specific sample preparation and exclusion criteria improve the reliability of Hf isotopic data in zircon analysis?
Enablement.Answer: The reliability of Hf isotopic data in zircon analysis is improved by applying exclusion criteria such as rejecting zircons with U-Pb age discordance over 10%, formation age greater than the model age, and Th/U ratios less than 0.05. These criteria help ensure that only zircons with reliable age and compositional data are included in the analysis, reducing potential errors from metamorphic origins.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do the geological characteristics of Hainan Island present challenges for interpreting its tectonic history using isotopic data?
Enablement.Answer: The geological characteristics of Hainan Island present challenges for interpreting its tectonic history due to the limited exposure and multistage deformation of crystalline basement rocks, which lead to diverse interpretations of its tectonic division. This necessitates additional evidence from stratigraphy, magmatism, geophysics, and paleobiogeography to clarify its tectonic characteristics.

Expectation.Question: What are the reasons for selecting specific exclusion criteria in the Hf isotopic data collection method, and how might this affect the expected outcomes?
Expectation.Answer: The exclusion criteria such as rejecting zircons with U-Pb age discordance over 10%, formation age bigger than the model age, and Th/U <0.05 were likely chosen to ensure the reliability and precision of the Hf isotopic data. These criteria help in filtering out zircons that may not accurately represent the crustal evolution history, potentially affecting the expected outcomes by providing a more consistent and interpretable dataset.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise in using Hf isotopic data to infer the historical relationship between Hainan Island and the Cathaysia Block, and how could these challenges affect expected research findings?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges include the limited exposure and multistage deformation of crystalline basement rocks, which can lead to diverse interpretations of tectonic divisions. These challenges might affect expected research findings by necessitating additional lines of evidence from stratigraphy, magmatism, geophysics, and paleobiogeography to confirm or clarify the historical relationship between Hainan Island and the Cathaysia Block.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the challenges faced in interpreting multistage deformed crystalline basement rocks for constructing tectonic histories, especially in regions like Hainan Island?
Judgmental.Answer: Interpreting multistage deformed crystalline basement rocks poses significant challenges due to limited exposure and complex deformation histories. These factors can lead to diverse interpretations of tectonic divisions, necessitating integration of multiple lines of evidence such as stratigraphy, magmatism, geophysics, and paleobiogeography to accurately construct tectonic histories in areas like Hainan Island.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why certain zircons are rejected during data collection based on their U-Pb age discordance and Th/U ratios.
Assertion.Answer: Zircons are rejected based on criteria like U-Pb age discordance over 10% and Th/U ratios less than 0.05 to ensure the purity of the data and minimize the potential for metamorphic origin, which could skew isotopic analyses and affect the accuracy of crustal growth interpretations.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the significance of using specific laser ablation parameters like beam size and repetition rate in zircon Hf isotopic analysis.
Assertion.Answer: The laser ablation parameters, such as a beam size of 45 μm, repetition rate of 8 Hz, and energy of 80 mJ, are calibrated to optimize the signal quality and accuracy of the Hf isotopic measurements. These parameters help achieve precise spot analyses on zircon grains, which are essential for detailed isotopic studies.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges involved in obtaining high-quality isotopic data from multistage deformed crystalline basement rocks and propose strategies to overcome these challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges in obtaining high-quality isotopic data from multistage deformed crystalline basement rocks include limited exposure and diverse tectonic interpretations. Strategies to overcome these challenges could involve deploying more comprehensive geological surveys to increase exposure, using advanced imaging techniques to better understand the deformation history, or integrating multidisciplinary data (stratigraphy, geophysics, paleobiogeography) to refine tectonic interpretations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please evaluate the potential for expanding the current dataset of Hf isotopic data from Hainan Island by identifying additional sources or methods of data collection that could provide deeper insights into the crustal evolution.
Request/Directive.Answer: The potential for expanding the current dataset of Hf isotopic data from Hainan Island could be realized by exploring additional Precambrian rock formations beyond the Shilu Group and Shihuiding Formation, employing remote sensing technologies to identify new sampling locations, or collaborating with international research teams to access diverse analytical techniques and methodologies that could enrich the existing data pool.
